metadata.title: Batch and flow hydrotreatment of water contaminated by trichloroethylene on active carbon supported nickel catalysts

Fig. 1 TEM images of a) CNR115, b) CNR115/2173 and c) CNR115/2173/26.54. Figures b and c presents turbostratic carbon structure. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns of 2 wt.% nickel catalysts after reduction step (red-Ni/CNR115, red-Ni/CNR115/2173, red-Ni/CNR115/2173/0.62, red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54). In figure * marks characteristic XRD signals for carbon turbostratic structure. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 TPR patterns of 2 wt.% Ni/CNR115, Ni/CNR115/2173, Ni/CNR115/2173/0.62, Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Kinetics of TCE hydrodechlorination in the presence of red-Ni/CNR115, red-Ni/CNR115/2173, red-Ni/CNR115/2173/0.62, red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Three cycles of TCE hydrodechlorination in aqueous phase on a) red-Ni/CNR115 b) red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54 catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Catalytic activity of red-Ni/CNR115, red-Ni/CNR115/2173, red-Ni/CNR115/2173/0.62 and red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54 in continuous flow liquid-phase TCE HDC. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 TEM images of red-Ni/CNR115 and TCE-spent-red-Ni/CNR115. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 TEM images of red-Ni/CNR115/2173 and TCE-spent-red-Ni/CNR115/2173. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 TEM images of red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54 and TCE-spent-red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 The Ni K-edge X-ray absorption spectrum measured for the a) red-Ni/CNR115/2173, b) TCE-spent-red-Ni/CNR115/2173, c) red-Ni/ CNR115/2173/0.62, d) TCE-spent-red-Ni/ CNR115/2173/0.62 and the fitted dominant spectral components. Fig. 10 Table 1 Textural parameters of studied carbons. Table 2 Catalyst k a [s−1] × 10−4 C b [%] r0 c [mol s−1 gPd −1] × 10-6 TOF d [s−1] × 10−3 Reaction with TCE red-Ni/CNR115 7.5 65 6.42 7.40 red-Ni/CNR115/2173 1.0 26 1.07 1.56 red-Ni/CNR115/2173/0.62 1.3 35 1.30 1.90 red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54 4.8 85 4.63 4.32 a the reaction rate constant k. b conversion after 150 min of the HDC process. c the initial reaction rate calculated from equation: r0 [mol s−1 gNi −1] = (nt=0 – nt=600)/(Δt × mNi), where nt=0 [mol] – the initial amount of TCE moles, nt=600 [mol] – amount of TCE moles after 600 s of reaction, Δt [s] = 600 – initial reaction time, mPd [g] – mass of Pd in the catalyst [40]. d TOF calculated from equation: TOF [s−1] = (r0 × M × 100)/D, where r0 [mol s−1 gNi −1] – the initial reaction rate, M [g mol−1] – atomic mass of Ni, D [%] – metal dispersion [41]. Table 4 Relative concentration of the Ni oxidation states estimated by XAS measurements. Table 4 Catalyst Relative concentration of the Ni oxidation states: Ni0 Ni2+ Ni3+ red-Ni/CNR115 65(1) % 0 % 35(2) % TCE-spent-red-Ni/CNR115 18(3) % 0 % 82(1) % red-Ni/CNR115/2173 97(2) % 3(2) % 0 % TCE-spent-red-Ni/CNR115/2173 95(1) % 0 % 5(1) % red-Ni/CNR115/2173/0.62 98(2) % 2(2) % 0 % TCE-spent-red-Ni/CNR115/2173/0.62 62(2) % 0 % 38(2) % red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54 87(1) % 0 % 13(2) % TCE-spent-red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54 60(1) % 0 % 40(1) % Batch and flow hydrotreatment of water contaminated by trichloroethylene on active carbon supported nickel catalysts Izabela I. Kamińska a Emil Kowalewski a Dmytro Lisovytskiy a Wojciech Błachucki a Wioletta Raróg-Pilecka b Dariusz Łomot a Anna Śrębowata a ⁎ a Institute of Physical Chemistry, Polish Academy of Sciences, ul. Kasprzaka 44/52, PL-01224, Warsaw, Poland Institute of Physical Chemistry Polish Academy of Sciences ul. Kasprzaka 44/52 Warsaw PL-01224 Poland Institute of Physical Chemistry, Polish Academy of Sciences, ul. Kasprzaka 44/52 PL-01224 Warsaw, Poland b Warsaw University of Technology, Faculty of Chemistry, ul. Noakowskiego 3, PL-00664, Warsaw, Poland Warsaw University of Technology Faculty of Chemistry ul. Noakowskiego 3 Warsaw PL-00664 Poland Warsaw University of Technology, Faculty of Chemistry, ul. Noakowskiego 3, PL-00664, Warsaw, Poland ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Herein, we thoroughly investigate the role of the turbostratic structure, surface area and pore size of activated carbon supports on catalytic behaviour of 2 wt% Ni catalysts in aqueous phase hydrotreatment of drinking water contaminated by trichloroethylene (TCE) in batch and flow mode. Carbon materials with different physicochemical properties were obtained from the same parent amorphous material via the pretreatment procedure. Both carbons and Ni catalysts were characterized by BET, TPR, XRD, STEM, HRTEM, XAS and TPH on different stages of their biography. The studies showed the significant impact of turbostratic support structure as well as pore distribution on catalytic behaviour of nickel catalysts. Ni uniformly dispersed on mesoporous turbostratic carbon exhibited the highest efficiency in water purification. Additionally, we showed unique results of continuous flow water purification. Application of the flow mode plays the beneficial role in water hydrotreatment, which was proved for the two catalysts with negligible activity in batch mode. Our promising results open completely new perspectives in water purification. Keywords Nickel Turbostratic carbon Trichloroethylene Batch hydrotreatment Flow hydrotreatment 1 Introduction Activated carbons are commonly used as adsorbents in almost every industry, including air and water treatment, catalysis, medicine, electronics and other technological applications [1–5]. Extremely high specific surface area (500–2500 m2  g−1) makes them the excellent adsorbents of many chemical compounds, such as chlorinated hydrocarbons (very harmful chemicals with carcinogenic and mutagenic properties [6–8]. Moreover, activated carbons are also non-toxic materials, inexpensive to produce (e.g from a renewable raw material source) and easy to dispose of via combustion [9]. Due to the resistance to corrosive conditions, they found application as the catalyst supports in hydrodechlorination (HDC) of chloroorganic compounds, where huge amount of HCl is formed [10–12]. Although their synthesis pathway and pretreatment conditions affect Metal/Carbon activity [13–15], some issues still need clarification. For example, contradictory information about the role of carbon ordering structure in catalytic properties of Metal/Support systems is still coming [16,17]. According to Munoz et al. [17] the catalyst with the high surface area and low ordered structure leads to higher HDC rates than the materials with high surface area but ordered structure. On the other hand, the latest studies of J.A. Baeza et al. [18] showed that Pd supported on graphitized carbon exhibited higher activity in comparison to Pd/non-graphitized carbon systems in aqueous-phase hydrodechlorination of 4-chlorophenol. This state of affairs gives the possibility of the elective interpretation of results and at its sole discretion. Most of the research related to the water purification from chloroorganic compounds are conducted in the batch reactor with gaseous H2 [12,16–18]. However there is also a possibility to use more advance method through a hydrogen – transfer, with formic acid as a source of hydrogen [19]. On the other hand, flow reactor is a promising technology emerging in variety of research area [20–22]. In our previous study [23] we successfully evaluate the possibility to use the same catalyst material independently in two modes: batch and flow. Nevertheless, there is strong need to determine more general dependencies that matter during transfer of the catalyst from batch to flow mode. Therefore this work is our contribution to the attempt to explain the role of the ordering support structure on catalytic activity of nickel nanoparticles in batch and continuous-flow hydrotreating of water contaminated by trichloroethylene (TCE) as model molecule. Nickel was chosen as an active phase due to its well-known and excellent reputation in the hydrodechlorination [24,25], but also because of its low cost, which is crucial for the potential application. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts synthesis A series of different active carbons were prepared from parent Norit CNR115 carbon (supplied by Norit B.V. Company) obtained from a renewable raw material source. The first sample (marked in the text as CNR115) was obtained by washing the parent carbon with large portions of redistilled water (to remove the dust fractions). One portion of washed CNR115 was subjected to a high-temperature heating at 2173 K for 2 h in argon atmosphere (obtained sample marked as CNR115/2173). Subsequent gasification of the sample CNR115/2173 with the H2O:Ar = 1:1 mixture at temperatures between 1033 and 1129 K for 5 h led to formation of active carbons characterized by a higher degree of burn-off (CNR115/2173/0.62 and CNR115/2173/26.54, where 0.62 and 26.54 indicate the percentage of mass loss). Four 2 wt.% Ni/active carbon catalysts were prepared by incipient-wetness impregnation from aqueous solution of NiCl2 · 6H2O (analytical purity, POCh, Gliwice, Poland). After impregnation step, the catalysts precursors were dried in air with infrared lamp and mixed for 24 h by rotary motion of a beaker. Before catalytic tests catalysts precursors were reduced at 673 K for 3 h in 10% H2/Ar flow (marked in text with red- prefix). 2.2 Physicochemical characterization Surface areas and porosities of carbon materials were measured with ASAP 2020 instrument from Micromeritics, employing the BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller), t-Plot, BJH (Barret-Joyner-Halenda) and HK (Horwath-Kawazoe) methods using nitrogen as an adsorbate. Before measurement of the adsorption isotherm at 77 K, each sample was evacuated at 473 K for 5 h in vacuum to clean their surfaces. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) of the catalysts precursors were carried out in 10% H2/Ar flow (25 cm3 min−1) in the range 260–800 K (temperature ramp 10 K min−1) in a glass flow system equipped with a Gow-Mac thermal conductivity detector. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) investigations were carried out using FEI TITAN Cubed electron microscope operated at an acceleration voltage of 300 keV and equipped with an Energy Dispersive X-ray (EDX) EDAX spectrometer. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed for samples after reduction step and after reactions with TCE, using a Siemens D5000 diffractometer with Ni filtered Cu-Kα radiation. Ni K-edge X-ray absorption spectra for selected fresh and spent catalysts were measured with a laboratory in-air X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) setup composed of an X-ray tube and a crystal X-ray spectrometer arranged in the von Hamos geometry. Detailed description of the XAS setup is included in SI. The energy calibration was done through comparison of a Ni K-edge XAS signal measured for a 5 μm-thick Ni foil with the shape of a reference Ni K-edge X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) [26]. The absorption spectra measured for the four samples of interest were subjected to linear baseline subtraction and normalization for energies below and above the absorption threshold. The relative concentrations of the Ni oxidation states: Ni0, Ni2+ and Ni3+ in the studied samples were extracted from the best fit of linear combination of the reference Ni0, Ni2+ and Ni3+ XAS spectra [26] to each of the measured spectrum. After reactions with TCE the nickel catalysts were investigated by Temperature-Programmed Hydrogenation (TPH) in 20% H2/He flow (25 cm3  min−1), in the range 300–850 K (temperature ramp – 10 K min−1) with a mass spectrometer MA200 (Dycor-Ametek, Pittsburgh). Energy dispersive X-ray fluorescence analysis (EDXRF) was carried out using MiniPal 4 equipment from PANalytical Co., with an Rh-tube and silicon drift detector (resolution 145 eV). EDXRF method was used to gain information on the elemental composition of liquid samples after catalytic experiments. 2.3 Catalytic reaction Hydrotreatment of water from TCE in batch operation mode was performed at 303 K in a 500 mL round bottomed flask equipped with a magnetic stirring bar and temperature controller. Reaction mixture consists of 350 mL MilliPore water, 2.0 μL of TCE (8 ppm of TCE) and 0.1 g of catalyst (details described earlier by Śrębowata et al. [10]. Reaction samples were taken at 0, 2, 5, 10, 15, 20, 60, 90, 120 and 150 min of the reaction. The reductive purification of water in flow mode was performed for two catalysts (with negligible activity in batch mode) in ThalesNano H-Cube Pro continuous-flow micro-reactor. TCE solution in MiliPore water (83 ppm of TCE) was flown through 0.15 g of the catalyst with a flow rate 1 ml/min (0.64 μmol/min of TCE). The catalyst was placed in a 70 mm long stainless steel cartridge (CatCart®70) with an ID of 4 mm. The hydrogen was generated in situ via water electrolysis. The reaction was conducted at 303 K under 10 bar of hydrogen for 210 min. Additionally, for 0.1 g of the selected nickel catalyst, the reaction was performed at 303 K under atmospheric pressure (results in Fig.S2). The substrate concentration and products distribution were monitored using a gas chromatographic system (Bruker 456-GC with ECD and FID detectors and Headspace SHS-40). All of the samples after reaction with TCE were marked with prefix TCE-spent-. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural parameters Textural parameters of the four carbon materials are collected in Table 1 . Amorphous CNR115 with very high specific surface area and large numbers of micropores was subjected to high temperature treatment, which resulted in a considerable carbon graphitization (formation of turbostratic structure) and undesirable drastic decrease of specific surface area and pores volume (material marked as CNR115/2173). In accordance with the literature data [10], this high-temperature pretreatment of CNR115 leads also to removal of functional groups from carbon surface (purification of its surface). The gasification in the H2O/Ar stream led to reconstruction of the porosity of carbon material with preservation of the turbostratic structure (materials marked as CNR115/2173/0.62 and CNR115/2173/26.54). Both TEM images Fig. 1 a-c of Norit carbons at different steps of its biography and XRD patterns for the differently pretreated carbon supported nickel samples (Fig. 2 ) confirmed a completely amorphous structure of the parent carbon CNR115 (Fig. 1a) and the more organized structure with the parallel graphene layers for CNR115/2173 (Fig. 1b) and CNR/2173/26.54 (Fig. 1c). Three thermally treated carbons (irrespective of their further gasification) show turbostratic two dimensional ordering (appropriate peaks marked as * in Fig. 2). First, a much better developed (0 0 2) peak is shifted upwards to ∼24.2°. Next, the (1 0 0) and (1 0 1) reflections merge into a single (1 0) peak (at ∼43.5°) and the (1 1) peak is manifested at ∼79°. This confirms that even far advanced gasification (26.54%) of highly heated carbon, which results in an almost complete recovery of specific surface area (Table 1), does not lead to loss of turbostratic character of the gasified samples, in agreement with earlier studies for similar carbon materials [27–29]. 3.2 Temperature – programmed reduction Temperature-programmed reduction experiments were carried out to determine the reducibility of nickel chloride precursor in four Ni/C materials. In line with earlier studies, [30,31] TPR results (Fig. 3 ) confirmed, that the application of activated carbon as a support allows to significantly decrease the reduction temperature of nickel precursor (even below 670 K). Because the overall reduction took place at temperature <740 K, the reduction conditions used in this study (10% H2/Ar, 673 K, 3 h) were sufficient for the complete reduction of carbon-supported nickel catalysts. Additionally, TPR data (Fig. 3) show the relationship between the reduction temperature of nickel chloride precursor and the kind of carbon support. TPR pattern for the nickel chloride supported on the “parent” (amorphous) CNR115 material shows the presence of two reduction peaks: one small at 660 K and the main reduction peak at 682 K. Application of CNR115/2173 as the support for nickel precursor resulted in one reduction peak with the maximum at 663 K. Partial gasification of carbon material with turbostratic structure moved the maximum of NiCl2 reduction into higher temperatures (for Ni/CNR115/2173/0.62 (Fig. 3)). Further gasification of carbon support material (Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54) led to two positive peaks: one at 645 K and the most prominent peak at 731 K. This broad and asymmetric reduction peak at 731 K is probably associated with the reduction of Ni2+, which is involved in strong interaction with the carbon support (a feature also observed by other groups [32,33]. 3.3 Catalytic results Catalytic reactions in batch and flow operation mode were carried out in the aqueous phase without any additional organic solvent, at relatively low reaction temperature (303 K). Blank tests confirmed that the chloroorganic compound removal did not proceed in the absence of the carbonaceous materials. On the other hand, all of the carbon materials showed efficiency in sorption of trichloroethylene from water without formation of any products both in batch and flow conditions (Fig. S1a,b). Correlation of the adsorption capacity with the physicochemical properties of the carbon materials clearly shows that a very high specific surface area and large pore volume play the crucial role in adsorption capacity (Table 1, Fig. S1a,b). Thus, the efficiency in the removal of chloroorganic compounds changes in order: CNR115/2173 (the turbostratic carbon with the surface area ˜1 m2 g−1) < CNR115/2173/0.62 < CNR115 < CNR115/2173/26.54 (turbostratic carbon with the surface area ˜1610 m2 g−1). Therefore, the nickel catalysts activities depend on both: the sorption properties of carbon material for organic compounds and the presence of nickel active phase. The introduction of the same small amounts of nickel to CNR115, CNR115/2173, CNR115/2713/0.62 and CNR115/2173.26.54 led to hydrodechlorination of TCE in batch mode (Fig. 4 ), with formation of ethane and ethylene as the main products of aqueous phase HDC of TCE over nickel catalysts. Comparative study between four Ni/C catalysts have shown significant differences between catalytic behaviour of nickel catalysts in the aqueous phase HDC batch process (Fig. 4). Application of the carbons with a very low specific surface area and pore volume as the supports for nickel (Table 1) resulted in red-Ni/CNR115/2173 and red-Ni/CNR115/2173/0.62 catalysts with very low activity. In the case of red-Ni/CNR115/2173 only 26% of TCE was removed from water after 150 min of the hydrodechlorination. On the other hand, the aqueous phase hydrodechlorination of TCE on red-Ni/CNR115 and red-Ni/CNR115/2173.26.54 led to very high conversion of chloroorganic compound (Fig. 4). The highest TCE conversion (85%) was obtained for red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54. The aqueous phase hydrodechlorination of trichloroethylene on Ni/C catalysts could be considered as pseudo-first-order reaction due to the predominant amounts of hydrogen compared to chloroorganic compound. According to the earlier studies by Munoz et al. [16], the kinetic data calculated for four metallic catalysts (Table 2 ) take into account both sorption processes on carbon supports and catalytic hydrodechlorination on Ni active centres. The reaction rate constant k, initial reaction rate r0 and TOF values calculated for HDC of TCE confirm the highest activity of nickel supported on amorphous CNR115 during the first 10 min of the reaction (Table 2, Fig. 4), what is in agreement with Munoz et al. [17], where the catalyst with the high surface area and low ordered structure leads to higher HDC rates than the materials with high surface area but ordered structure [17]. However, after the first 20 min of hydrodehlorination, the situation has changed. Red-Ni/CNR115 activity was lower than that observed for the nickel supported on turbostratic carbon CNR115/2173/26.54. Finally, the highest overall conversion of TCE was obtained for red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54 with similar nickel particle size, surface are and pore volume like Ni supported on amorphous CNR115 but with one crucial difference - ordered structure of carbon surface without any functional groups on it. Our results are in line with latest studies of J.A. Baeza et al. [18] where Pd supported on graphitized carbon exhibited higher activity in comparison to Pd/non-graphitized carbon systems in aqueous-phase hydrodechlorination of 4-chlorophenol. They also confirm our previous studies respecting the beneficial role of the supports with ordered structure on Metal/Support systems activity in the aqueous phase TCE hydrodechlorination [34]. In accordance to earlier studies [18,35] the highest activity of red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54 could be explain by the reducing ability of the graphitized carbon support metal–support interactions (MSI) through electron transfer, favouring hydrogen spillover on the metal–support interface, thus improving the activity [36]. Additionally, analogically like in the case of Pd catalysts, initial Ni0/(Ni2++Ni3+) ratio (Table 4) could also affect activity of nickel catalysts. And although the activity of our best catalyst is similar or slightly worse, than that obtained for Pd, Ir on Ni supported on different ordered materials [23,34,37], it should be stressed here, that the results obtained for cheap 2 wt % Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54 are very promising. To check the stability of the most active catalysts, red-Ni/CNR115 and red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54 were investigated three times in the hydrodechlorination of TCE in batch mode (Fig. 5 a,b). Both Ni catalysts exhibited relatively high stability during three cycles of TCE HDC. However, red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54 with turbostratic structure of the support showed better stability. Only negligible differences in TCE conversion after 150 min of subsequent reactions could be related rather to catalyst mass loss as a result of filtration and drying between the cycles, than the deactivation by the formation of deposits on catalysts support. Additionally, EDXRF analysis of the liquid sample after catalytic experiment did not show any amounts of nickel within the limits of the detection. Therefore, the effect of nickel leaching to reaction mixture (if any) is rather negligible. In the context of growing interest in performing of water purification in flow mode [38] the materials with negligible capacity in batch mode (CNR115/2173, CNR115/2173/0.62 and nickel catalysts supported on these carbon materials) were investigated in the liquid continuous flow water hydrotreatment. In these experiments TCE concentration exceeded 8000 times the acceptable level of this substance in drinking water. Both turbostratic carbons and nickel catalysts had efficiently purified water from trichloroethylene (Fig. 6 , Fig.S.1b). The sorption properties of two carbons had decreased in time, and had influence on the catalytic behaviour of red-Ni/CNR115/2173 in contrast to red-Ni/CNR115, red-Ni/CNR115/2173/0.62, and red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54 with rather stable and high (>85%) activity. Additionally, the overall activity of red-Ni/CNR115, red-Ni/CNR115/2173/0.62, and red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54 in the experiment conducted for 25 h (Fig. 6) could be considered as rewarding, especially in comparison to the activity of the same amount of 1.57 wt.% Pd/C in the experiment conducted for over 25 h [21]. Figs. 6 and S1b show that both CNR115, CNR115/2173/0.62, CNR115/2173/26.54 and nickel catalysts had effectively purified water during the 25 h of the process. However, the sorption properties of carbon had decreased in time and finally stabilized on a level C/C0 ˜ 1. On the other hand, red-Ni/CNR115, red-Ni/CNR115/2173/0.62 and red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54 showed over 80% of the efficiency, without any symptoms of deactivation. It could mean that the significant conversion of active Ni0 to Ni3+ (Table 4) and nickel nanoparticles redispersion during hydrodechlorination did not significantly affect catalytic activity of these catalysts during 25 h of the reaction. Additional experiment performed under atmospheric pressure with 0.1 g of red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54 (Fig S2) showed that even at the atmospheric pressure our catalyst is still very active. Our promising results obtained in continuous-flow conditions (Fig. 6) for the catalysts with negligible activity in batch mode (Fig. 4) open completely new perspectives in water purification. And although the batch mode is still the most widely used in aqueous phase hydrodechlorination [38] and allows to remove higher amounts of TCE per unit of time, the application of the flow mode eliminates some difficulties typical for a batch reactor such as: the application of the long-term processes, external separation between catalysts and products, and the loss of powder catalyst during separation operations; ipso facto making the flow mode an attractive alternative for batch conditions. 3.4 Transmision electron microscopy Figs. 7–9 present TEM images of red-Ni/CNR115 and spent-TCE-red-Ni/CNR115, red-Ni/CNR115/2173 and TCE-spent-red-Ni/CNR115/2173, red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54 and TCE-spent-red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54. The average nickel particles size in spent-TCE-red-Ni/CNR115 is only a little smaller than in red-Ni/CNR115, what indicates that the TCE hydrodechlorination to some extent influences on the size of particles. Similarly, the lack of significant differences between TEM results of red-, TCE-spent-red-CNR115/2173/26.54 indicates that carbon turbostratic structure and nickel particles size have not been affected by the hydrodechlorination process. Whereas, in the case of Ni supported on turbostratic CNR115/2173, considerable re-dispersion of the metallic phase under reaction conditions could be observed (Fig. 8, Table 3 ). This phenomenon could be explained by the textural parameters of this carbon material (Table 1). Very small specific surface area and lack of porosity in case of CNR115/2173 lead to creation of the large nickel species capable of migration to the surface. It could mean that that only well-developed morphology with turbostratic character of the carbonaceous surface favours the formation of well dispersed and resistant to redispersion or agglomeration nickel nanoparticles. 3.5 X-ray absorption spectroscopy X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) around Ni K-edge measurements were performed to determine the relative concentrations of the different Ni oxidation states in the selected samples. Fig. 10 a–d shows an example of a XAS spectrum for the a) red-Ni/CNR115/2173, b) TCE-spent-red-Ni/CNR115/2173, c) red-Ni/ CNR115/2173/0.62, d) TCE-spent-red-Ni/ CNR115/2173/0.62 and its deconvolution using as reference the spectra reported elsewhere [26]. All the measured spectra were fitted with three components, namely Ni0, Ni2+ and Ni3+. Table 4 contains the obtained relative concentrations of the different Ni oxidation states in all red- and spent- nickel catalysts investigated by XAS. In red-Ni/CNR115/2173 and red-Ni/ CNR115/2173/0.62 mainly the Ni oxidation state 0 and a small fraction of Ni2+ were observed, in opposite to red-Ni/CNR115 and red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54, where besides Ni0, fraction of Ni3+ was detected. This phenomenon could be related with the lower resistance of slightly smaller nickel particles in red-Ni/CNR115 and red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54 on the presence of different functional groups on carbon support (red-Ni/CNR115) and electron deficiency of turbostratic carbon support. After exposure of red-Ni/CNR115/2173 to trichloroethylene the Ni2+ component vanished and about the same amount of the 3+ oxidation state was formed. Exposure to TCE of the red-Ni/CNR115, red-Ni/CNR115/2173/0.62 and red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54 samples resulted in a conversion of a significant amount of Ni0 to Ni3+,which maybe the cause of nickel nanoparticles redispersion (Table 3, Fig.8) and /or the exposition of nickel catalysts on electron- deficient substrate (trichloroethylene) [39]. 3.6 Temperature – programmed hydrogenation During Temperature–Programmed Hydrogenation TPH of spent samples the particular attention was focused on the changes of m/z 15, 28 and 36 (elimination of CH4, C2Hx and HCl, respectively). Analysis of TPH results showed the formation of carbon containing species, mainly on the most active catalysts (spent-red-Ni/CNR115/2173/26.54 and spent-red-Ni/CNR115; Figs. S3, S4). The carbonaceous deposits were strong bounded with nickel surface and desorbed at temperature range 580–750 K. Increasing of the signals at temperatures >750 K could indicate the gasification of carbons support. Deposits containing chlorine were not observed during hydrodechlorination of TCE in the aqueous phase (Fig. S5). 4 Conclusions The catalytic behaviour of nickel catalysts depends on the properties of the carbon supports. Their surface area, pore structure, hydrophobic and turbostratic character have an advantageous effect on the nickel catalysts efficiency and stability in TCE removal from water. Thus, the incipient wetness impregnation of turbostratic carbon (CNR115/2173/26.54) by nickel chloride solution leads to formation of resistant for leaching and agglomeration catalysts and an effective material for catalytic removal of trichloroethylene from water. In the view of the obtained results for nickel catalysts with negligible activity in batch conditions, the application of the flow mode opens the completely new perspectives for water purification. coredata.dc:description: Herein, we thoroughly investigate the role of the turbostratic structure, surface area and pore size of activated carbon supports on catalytic behaviour of 2 wt% Ni catalysts in aqueous phase hydrotreatment of drinking water contaminated by trichloroethylene (TCE) in batch and flow mode. Carbon materials with different physicochemical properties were obtained from the same parent amorphous material via the pretreatment procedure. Both carbons and Ni catalysts were characterized by BET, TPR, XRD, STEM, HRTEM, XAS and TPH on different stages of their biography. The studies showed the significant impact of turbostratic support structure as well as pore distribution on catalytic behaviour of nickel catalysts. Ni uniformly dispersed on mesoporous turbostratic carbon exhibited the highest efficiency in water purification. Additionally, we showed unique results of continuous flow water purification. Application of the flow mode plays the beneficial role in water hydrotreatment, which was proved for the two catalysts with negligible activity in batch mode. Our promising results open completely new perspectives in water purification.
coredata.dc:title: Batch and flow hydrotreatment of water contaminated by trichloroethylene on active carbon supported nickel catalysts
